topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Karri Saarinen and Linear, highlighting Linear’s unusual product culture (craft-first, no A/B tests, minimal PMs, project-based teams) and previews topics like hiring, product building, and growth.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor reads for Mercury (startup banking) and Composer (AI-assisted algorithmic trading, now with retirement accounts).

topics.title: What Linear is and why it exists
topics.summary: Karri explains Linear as a modern project/issue tracking tool, shares customer examples and company stats (profitable, net negative burn), and describes the founders’ motivation: existing tools felt clunky and legacy-driven.

topics.title: Creating space for craft without perfection paralysis
topics.summary: Karri describes how Linear balances craft with speed: ship early internally, then to opt-in customers, and only polish for general release—accepting small timeline slips to protect quality.

topics.title: Why Linear has almost no PMs
topics.summary: Karri argues craft improves when engineers/designers own projects end-to-end; PM responsibilities are distributed via a project lead model, enabled by hiring people who want broader ownership.

topics.title: The role of Linear’s head of product
topics.summary: Karri explains why they hired Nan Yu (initially for a data/insights feature) and how the PM role is positioned: steer direction and alignment at a higher level rather than writing specs and attending every meeting.

topics.title: Operating without PMs: requirements and trade-offs
topics.summary: They discuss what it takes to function with few PMs: engineers/designers must do coordination work, not everyone wants that, and hiring must assess product thinking and communication—not just technical skill.

topics.title: When design is a real competitive differentiator
topics.summary: Karri explains why design matters more as categories mature and choices proliferate; design and brand set expectations and can drive adoption, but they must be paired with real product value.

topics.title: Building an authentic brand over time
topics.summary: Karri emphasizes brand as authentic, cumulative behavior (voice, customer treatment, product/website quality), citing Airbnb as an example of brand being embedded in everything the company does.

topics.title: How Linear reviews design and decides it’s done
topics.summary: Karri describes lightweight, ongoing reviews (weekly/biweekly demos, sponsor review by founders/head of product) and a hands-on “try it yourself” quality bar before broad release, with examples like comment threading and project updates.

topics.title: The Linear Method: opinionated software
topics.summary: Karri explains why Linear advocates opinionated workflows: strong defaults reduce cognitive overhead, prevent teams from inventing divergent processes, and enable more optimized experiences for a clear target user.

topics.title: Cycles: focus mechanism similar to sprints
topics.summary: Karri defines cycles as an optional, automated cadence to help teams commit to a short list of priorities, reduce distraction from infinite backlogs, and create clarity when priorities change.

topics.title: No feature-level metrics: intuition plus customer closeness
topics.summary: Karri explains they avoid feature-level metric goals and A/B testing; instead they combine “science” (continuous customer conversations, shared channels, targeted data questions) with “magic” (informed judgment), accepting occasional mistakes as part of the process.
